overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a methodical approach to time-series forecasting with a strong focus on data quality issues. It begins by identifying suspicious constant values in the last 24 hours as potential missing data, proceeds through data imputation using hourly averaging, and settles on a simple yet practical forecasting method. The analysis shows careful consideration of alternatives like SARIMA before opting for pattern-based averaging due to data limitations.
common_data_patterns: Suspicious constant values (treated as missing data)
No clear long-term trend (limited data scope)
Handling of missing values through imputation
key_insights: Constant values in time-series may indicate missing data requiring imputation
Hourly averaging of corresponding time points is effective for handling daily seasonality
Limited historical data (96 hours) constrains complex model selection
Imputed data may not add new information if derived from existing patterns
Pattern repetition provides viable forecasts when data is insufficient for advanced modeling
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex with thorough data diagnostics and method evaluation, though ultimately employs simplified heuristics due to data constraints. Balances statistical considerations (seasonality, imputation) with practical implementation.
